meta.title: Use advanced processes to develop a digital technologies outcome
meta.purpose: This achievement standard involves using advanced processes to develop a digital technologies outcome.

grade_descriptors.N1: Evidence does not reach the minimum threshold for Achieved-level indicators.
grade_descriptors.N2: Some Achieved-level indicators are met, but not enough to satisfy all required Achieved criteria.
grade_descriptors.A3: All Achieved-level indicators are met; no Merit-level indicator meets the Merit threshold.
grade_descriptors.A4: All Achieved indicators are met and at least one Merit indicator is met, but overall performance is below the Merit threshold.
grade_descriptors.M5: All Achieved indicators are met and the Merit threshold is reached; no Excellence-level indicator meets the Excellence threshold.
grade_descriptors.M6: All Achieved indicators are met, all Merit indicators are met, and at least one Excellence indicator is met, but overall performance is below the Excellence threshold.
grade_descriptors.E7: All Achieved and Merit indicators are met and the Excellence threshold is reached, but not all Excellence indicators are met.
grade_descriptors.E8: All Achieved, Merit, and Excellence indicators are met.

omis.description: Uses appropriate project management tools and techniques to plan the development of the digital technologies outcome.
omis.detection_hint: Provide artefacts (e.g., task plan, timeline, milestones) showing planning for development tasks. Planning the outcome’s features alone does not count; it must plan the development process. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: using appropriate project management tools and techniques to plan the development of a digital technologies outcome
a table or spreadsheet plan showing tasks/milestones, dates, and status (to-do, doing, done)
use of a project management tool like Trello or Monday.com showing tasks/milestones, dates, and status (to-do, doing, done)
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p2 (Explanatory Note 2); Moderator commentary: Assessment guidance

omis.description: Decomposes the outcome into smaller components.
omis.detection_hint: Show an explicit breakdown (list/diagram) of components or sub-systems. Mentioning generic parts without a deliberate decomposition is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: decomposing the outcome into smaller components

omis.description: Trials the components of the digital technologies outcome.
omis.detection_hint: Include trial records with purpose and observations used to inform decisions. Running something without recording intent or findings is not trialling. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: trialling the components of the digital technologies outcome
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p2 (Explanatory Note 2); Moderator commentary: Assessment guidance

omis.description: Tests that the digital technologies outcome functions as intended.
omis.detection_hint: Provide test evidence mapped to intended functions (pass/fail or screenshots). Bug lists or intentions without confirmation do not count. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: testing that the digital technologies outcome functions as intended
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p2 (Explanatory Note 2); Moderator commentary: Assessment guidance

omis.detection_hint: Explain at least two relevant implications (e.g., privacy, accessibility, cultural appropriateness, usability, legal, ethical). The student must identify and explain how the implication applies to their outcome, and state what the outcome needs to do or include to meet the implication. Explanations should occur early in the design or development process so they inform the outcome’s design/development. Listing implications without explanation is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: documentation explaining privacy issues when storing personal information in a database, and how the system will address them
explanation of accessibility needs (e.g., colour-blind users) and design choices made to ensure access
discussion of cultural appropriateness, such as correct use of Te Reo Māori and fair representation of cultures
explanation of how usability heuristics (error prevention, clear feedback) are applied in the outcome
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p2 (Explanatory Note 2 & 4); Moderator commentary: Assessment guidance; Relevant Implications resource

omis.description: Effectively uses project management and version control tools and techniques to manage development.
omis.detection_hint: Show evidence of effective management (e.g., archived file versions or folder structures, milestone updates, planning updates or completions, collaboration logs). Naming tools without demonstrating management use is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: effectively using ongoing project management (e.g., updates, status changes) and version control tools and techniques
archived versions of code such as app.py, HTML files, or web app components with clear version markers (_v1, _v2, etc.)
entire folders saved as iterative versions (e.g., project_v1, project_v2) showing progression over time
ongoing use of a project management tool with updated task statuses, added milestones, or adjusted deadlines
evidence of collaboration logs or commit history demonstrating changes over time
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p2 (Merit); Moderator commentary: Assessment guidance

omis.description: Designs and applies systematic test cases, including valid, invalid, boundary, and edge cases, mapped to intended functions.
omis.detection_hint: Look for structured test artefacts (e.g., test tables or automated tests) covering valid/invalid inputs and boundary values, with Expected vs Actual results and Pass/Fail. Ad-hoc or purely narrative testing is insufficient.
success_examples: boundary testing table for inputs (e.g., 9 / 10 / 60 / 61) with Expected→Actual→Pass/Fail
automated unit tests that assert function behaviour for edge cases
screen-captured evidence of systematic test runs linked to user stories or functions
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p2 (Merit – testing depth); Moderator commentary: Assessment guidance

omis.description: Trials multiple components and/or techniques for the same sub-problem and selects the most suitable.
omis.detection_hint: Contrast different approaches for the same sub-problem and justify the selection. Listing two attempts without comparison is not selection. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: trialling multiple components and/or techniques
selecting those which are most suitable
comparing two database structures (e.g., denormalised vs. normalised) for performance or simplicity and selecting the most suitable
trialling alternative algorithms for the same function (e.g., custom sort vs. built-in sort) and justifying the choice
evaluating two UI layouts through quick user tests and choosing the layout with fewer errors/misclicks
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p2 (Merit); Moderator commentary: Assessment guidance

omis.description: Uses information from testing and trialling to improve the functionality of the outcome.
omis.detection_hint: Link specific test/trial findings to implemented changes that enhance functionality. Bug fixes alone do not constitute improvement. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: using information appropriately from testing and trialling to improve the functionality
after boundary tests revealed failures, implemented input validation and re-tested to confirm reliability
rewrote a slow function after profiling to improve response time and verified with a new test
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p2 (Merit); Moderator commentary: Assessment guidance

omis.description: Shows that the outcome addresses the relevant implications previously explained.
omis.detection_hint: Provide explicit design/implementation evidence that responds to the earlier implications. Restating implications without demonstrating changes is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: addressing relevant implications
use of ALT tags in HTML code to support accessibility
documented design decision to select colour palettes that are accessible to colour-blind users
implementation of privacy measures (e.g., excluding personal identifiers in stored data)
ensuring cultural appropriateness by using correct Te Reo Māori spelling and macrons
adding usability features such as error messages or clear navigation that respond to previously identified issues
legal/IP compliance by replacing unlicensed images with CC-licensed assets and providing attribution
future-proofing via modular code and documented update steps
functionality/cross-compatibility verification across major browsers/devices
health & safety warnings or safe-use guidance where relevant (e.g., hardware projects)
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p2 (Merit); Moderator commentary: Assessment guidance; Relevant Implications resource

omis.description: Discusses how information from planning, testing, and trialling assisted the development of a high-quality outcome.
omis.detection_hint: Provide a coherent discussion that links specific planning/testing/trialling information to how it assisted the final outcome’s quality. Show that improvements went beyond bug fixes to enhance usability, efficiency, accessibility, reliability, or maintainability.
success_examples: discussing how the information from planning, testing and trialling
development of a high-quality outcome
explains how user feedback exposed accessibility barriers and how redesign improved task completion rates
shows that performance profiling informed algorithm changes that reduced load time, improving user experience

omis.description: Integrates a range of information sources (planning, testing and trialling of components) within the discussion of how the outcome was developed.
omis.detection_hint: Look for explicit references to multiple distinct information sources (e.g., planning notes, structured testing results, trialling comparisons, user feedback, external research) tied into the development discussion. The student must not only mention these sources but also explain how each informed their decisions.
success_examples: a range of sources
user feedback, trialling and research
planning notes and testing outcomes informed design decisions
triangulates user testing results, error logs, and published heuristics to justify UI revisions
